origination.corpname: University of Michigan. School of Public Health.

did.abstract: The Tecumseh Community Health Study is an ongoing prospective epidemiological study of a natural community's health and disease status. It focuses on the community of Tecumseh, Michigan, and began through the University of Michigan's School of Public Health with a 1957 canvass of all households. The study includes all newcomers to the community until 1970, after which only previous residents were followed. The Tecumseh Community Health Study records consist of materials outlining the project planning and management of the study, the initial community survey, materials from rounds one through three of data collection, and later community surveys and follow-up studies.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Donated by the University of Michigan School of Public Health (donor no. 1756) in March and April 2013.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: Tecumseh Community Health Study records are open for research except for certain records restricted by statute or university policy. Restricted material includes personnel-related files, including search, review, promotion, and tenure files; student educational records; client/patient records; and records of executive officers of the university.

The Tecumseh Community Health Study records include restricted material in the following categories:
Patient/Client Records -- Box 29

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Tecumseh Community Health Study records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Tecumseh Community Health Study is an ongoing prospective epidemiological study of a natural community's health and disease status, conducted through the University of Michigan's School of Public Health and focusing on the community of Tecumseh, Michigan. Originally conceived by Dr. Thomas Francis, Jr., the study began under the direction of Dr. Robert Horton, an epidemiologist from the University of Michigan's School of Public Health.

The purpose of the Tecumseh Community Health Study was to research the distribution of disease and disability in a natural community, and to develop, formulate, and conduct investigations into factors possibly related to the development of various chronic diseases, especially those involving the heart and circulation. The ultimate goal of the study was to gain further insight into methods for early detection, measures of susceptibility, preclinical disorders, and prevention. The study involved integrated investigations in the field, laboratory, and clinic in search of causative mechanisms and ecological interrelations. The target diseases investigated were primarily cardiovascular disorders, diabetes, hypertension, chronic respiratory disease, and rheumatic disorders.

The study examined the approximately 10,000 residents of Tecumseh, Michigan and explored the hypothesis that disease results from biological maladjustment, and therefore that the environment may strongly influence health and disease. The study also assumed that the familial aspect of disease occurrence is equally important. If either genetic or environmental factors are operative, those conducting the study believed that this would likely lead to aggregation of disease within families and kindreds since family members share their environment as well as their genetic background.

The study launched with a 1957 to 1958 canvass of all households in Tecumseh, and continued through two general surveillance studies of the Tecumseh community and three rounds, or "cycles," of data collection from 1959 to 1969. The terms "rounds" and "cycles" are used interchangeably in this collection, just as they were throughout the Tecumseh study. The two general surveillance studies, which took place in 1965 and 1966, were based upon the same concept as the original canvass of the Tecumseh community, and involved gathering data about the population and general health of the Tecumseh community as a whole, including any new residents who moved to the area during this period. The three rounds, or "cycles," of data collection involved studying specific health conditions and diseases within the Tecumseh community and gathering raw data to reflect this study. Round 1 (First Cycle) took place from 1959 to 1961, Round 2 (Second Cycle) was conducted from 1962 to 1965, and Round 3 (Third Cycle) lasted from 1967 to 1969. Each cycle focused on collecting data about various disorders within the Tecumseh community, including cardiovascular disorders, diabetes, hypertension, chronic respiratory disease, and rheumatic disorders.

All follow-up studies that took place after 1970 focused only on those residents who were included in the initial rounds of data collection during the 1960s. All information gleaned from the study came from data that was collected through baseline medical history interviews, medical examinations, clinical measurements, laboratory work, and electrocardiograms. The major variable groups involved in the study included demographic information, family history of major diseases, systematic review of present and past symptoms and conditions, smoking and drinking habits, physical examinations, measurements and laboratory work, and electrocardiogram results.

arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into three sub-groups with four to eight series within each sub-group. The three sub-groups are Project Planning and Management; Initial Community Survey and Rounds 1-3 of Data Collection; and Later Community Surveys and Follow-Up Studies.

Given the extensive scope, duration, and staffing of the community-wide project that these materials represent, they have been arranged into three sub-groups based on indications of provenance from the material itself. To the extent possible, each subgroup is arranged in chronological order and descriptive titles echo terminology from original folder labels.

scopecontent.p: The Tecumseh Community Health Study records collection consists of materials outlining the project planning and management of the study, the initial community survey, materials from rounds one through three of data collection, and later community surveys and follow-up studies. Records include conceptual documentation, organizational charts, questionnaires and forms, meeting minutes and agenda, reports, correspondence, budgets, and other study material. In addition to inquiries related to early medical diagnosis and treatment of many conditions, the collection documents an early example of large-scale project management and collaborative grant administration. The collection may also be of interest to researchers studying the history of survey research methodology, data management, and bio-statistical analysis techniques.

scopecontent.p: The Project Planning and Management subgroup (14.3 linear feet, 1940-1983) contains four series: Office of Professor and Chairman, Department of Epidemiology; Center for Research in Diseases of the Heart; Existing Surveys, Similar Projects, and Related Studies; and Tecumseh Project History and Visual Material.

scopecontent.p: The Center for Research in Diseases of the Heart series (3 linear feet, 1956-1972) includes organizational charts, correspondence, meeting minutes, and budget and project information from this center at the University of Michigan. The Center for Research in Diseases of the Heart is also referred to as the Cardiovascular Center and/or the Cardiovascular Research Center (CRC).

scopecontent.p: The Existing Surveys, Similar Projects, and Related Studies series (1 linear foot, 1950-1967) contains materials from the California Health Survey, the Canada Sickness Survey, the National Health Survey, and the Professional Activity Study. The files on these related projects were maintained by the Tecumseh Community Health Study as background resources to help enrich the methodology and findings of the study.

scopecontent.p: The Initial Community Survey and Rounds 1-3 of Data Collection subgroup (10.2 linear feet, 1950-1972) contains eight series: Original Canvas of the Tecumseh Community; Round 1 (First Cycle); Round 2 (Second Cycle); General Surveillance 1; General Surveillance 2 and Round 3 (Third Cycle); Tables from Rounds 1-3 of Data Collection; Code Books from Rounds 1-3 of Data Collection; and Code Decks from Rounds 1-3 of Data Collection.

scopecontent.p: The Round 1 (First Cycle) series (1.4 linear feet, 1959-1961) includes clinic, reviewing, and interview forms from Cycle I, as well as materials from the dental study, diet study, and tuberculosis and cystic fibrosis study. Other materials include information on expert consultants and morbidity listings, and material from the Influenza Follow-Up, Kindred CHD Follow-Up, and Sample 10 Follow-Up.

scopecontent.p: The General Surveillance 2 and Round 3 (Third Cycle) series (2.5 linear feet, 1966-1969) contains coding forms and questionnaires from Cycle III, correspondence, clinic and reviewing forms, self-administered health reports, and materials from the Cycle III B Group, Diet Study, Sample 10, Hong Kong Flu Vaccine, and Work and Leisure Time Study. General Surveillance 2 is paired with Round 3 (Third Cycle) in this series because General Surveillance 2 was considered to be part of Round 3 during the Tecumseh study. As evidenced in the original order of these materials, which has been maintained in this collection, materials from General Surveillance 2 were directly intertwined with some materials from Round 3.

Code Books from Rounds 1-3 of Data Collection, 1959-1969

scopecontent.p: The Code Books from Rounds 1-3 of Data Collection series (0.3 linear feet, 1959-1969) contains four samples of code books from Cycles I through III. These code books were specifically selected as historically informative examples of the coding procedures and practices undertaken to process the data gathered throughout the Tecumseh Community Health Study. These code books mostly contain raw data written in computer coding language, and as such, the majority of the code books were weeded from this collection.

did.unittitle: 4 examples of Code Books used during Tecumseh Study
Code Decks from Rounds 1-3 of Data Collection, 1959-1969

scopecontent.p: The Code Decks from Rounds 1-3 of Data Collection series (2.5 linear feet, 1959-1969) includes forms and cards from each study conducted throughout Cycles I through III of data collection, organized chronologically by form and card number. The data contained within these code decks corresponds directly to the code books, but is more historically valuable since the code decks are written in English rather than computer coding language. The information in the code decks will allow the researcher to discover the specific information that those conducting the Tecumseh Community Health Study were looking for, and how this data was coded so that it could be processed by a large computer system.

Later Community Surveys and Follow-Up Studies, 1970-1986

scopecontent.p: The Later Community Surveys and Follow-Up Studies subgroup (3.8 linear feet, 1970-1986) contains seven series: Code Decks from Follow-Up Studies; Special Lipid Study; Heart Center; General Materials from Follow-Up Studies; Field Studies, 1971-1972; Blood Pressure Study; and Patient Health Files.

The Code Decks from Follow-Up Studies series (0.5 linear feet, 1970-1978) includes forms and cards from the Special Lipid Study, Chronic Respiratory Disease Study, and Blood Pressure Study, organized chronologically by form and card number. The information in the code decks will allow the researcher to discover the specific information that those conducting the Tecumseh Community Health Study were looking for, and how this data was coded so that it could be processed by a large computer system.

scopecontent.p: The Special Lipid Study series (0.4 linear feet, 1970) contains forms, questionnaires, and correspondence from this study.

scopecontent.p: The Heart Center series (0.3 linear feet, 1970-1975) includes forms, correspondence, and meeting minutes from the University of Michigan Heart Center during this period.

The General Materials from Follow-Up Studies series (0.5 linear feet, 1970-1986) contains reports, procedures, meeting minutes, forms, and questionnaires from acute illness surveillance, the Institute of Social Research, diet study, pregnancy study, and chronic respiratory disease study.

scopecontent.p: The Field Studies series (0.6 linear feet, 1971-1972) includes correspondence, procedures, summaries, reports, and questionnaires from various field studies conducted during this period, including dental and diet studies, lung function tests, dwelling and household unit listings, and a thyroid study.

scopecontent.p: The Blood Pressure Study series (1.2 linear feet, 1977) contains correspondence, forms, reports, and questionnaires, clinic lists and schedules, information on high blood pressure in the young, and pregnancy history forms.

scopecontent.p: The Patient Health Files series (0.3 linear feet, 1977) includes the personal health history files of four patients from the Tecumseh Community Health Study, gathered in 1977. These files are restricted for 100 years from their date of creation.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: An earlier historical overview and data archive for the years 1959-1969 have been digitized for the Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) collections (ICPSR 8969)
